author: _shemnon
content: Right, but that analysis in the thread was pre-verkle. Data privacy across contracts can be violated in both  trie models with a proper trie proof passed into a call, so extsload would make it much cheaper and more practical. The OO encapsulation construct is still useful, but other contact's storage should not be confused with a secure enclave.  My main objection to extsload is still the fragile developer experience.

author: sky.cactus
content: I believe data privacy can only be violated for historic state, not current state?

author: sky.cactus
content: That may not matter for this conversation I guess.

author: _shemnon
content: Mostly correct, you can prove the state at the beginning of the current block.  So there is a narrow window of privacy. You also have to load in a whole bunch of data since i believe your only good hook is the prior block hash.

author: sky.cactus
content: I have written contracts for on-chain proofs.  I haven't checked recently, but the gas cost (primarily calldata costs) was around 600,000 for proof of a few adjacent storage slots.
